awd_titl_txt: Unconventional Heteroanion Ceramics: 2D Layered Seleno- and Thio-Phosphates
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The performance of silicon-based architecture is now approaching fundamental limits governed by physics. Thus, there is a critical need for new materials and novel structures that may follow the meteoritic growth of conventional silicon microelectronic technology of the past few decades. In this context, new scientific opportunities are presented by emerging two-dimensional (2D) materials, especially those whose composition can be tailored and optimized. Ever since the discovery of graphene, a single 2D layer of carbon atoms, which was the subject of Physics Nobel prize a decade ago, other 2D layered structures are being pursued worldwide. This research focuses on a new class of 2D layered materials, called chalcophosphates where phosphorous, sulphur and analogous elements are arranged in an intricate planar mosaic pattern. This research develops and explores metal chalcophosphates as a new class of ceramic materials for their magnetic, ferroelectric, and coupled properties, with unusual quantum behavior. This unique combination of non-linear phenomena provide rich opportunities to advance science of ceramics, and creates a potential platform for new generation of magneto-electronic devices. This emerging research field is likely to generate new technology industries and require workforce with extensive hands-on expertise in novel multicomponent ceramic materials and their characterization. As a result, research activities are integrated with educational and societal outreach initiatives, anchored by the unique platform for 2D layered ceramic materials. The other broader impact goals include training of undergraduate and graduate students in advanced materials research and incorporation of research results into course and curricula. Through an innovative "Materials-Journalism" program, Medill school journalism students immerse to witness the scientific process and report their findings in their journalism blogs and reports. Conversely, the research team members learn journalism practices of story-telling and how to synthesize complex scientific undertaking into meaningful discourse with the public. Collectively, the research advances scientific insights with prospects for technology breakthroughs in the new class of 2D ceramics, with educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and societal outreach through the journalism initiative.
 
TECHNICAL DETAILS: This research revolves around synthesis and advanced characterization of 2D layered metal chalcophosphates (MCP), i.e. thiophosphates and selenophosphates, as a new and novel class of 2D layered ceramic systems. Anchored on a variety of possible chemical combinations, especially with heteroanions, the synthesized structures are readily amenable to extensive multimodal characterization methods to map their complex structural characteristics in conjunction with their linear and non-linear properties. Of specific interest are single- and few layered 2D structures to explore the role of spatial and dimensional constraints. This goal is accomplished by classical mechanical exfoliation as well as vapor-based deposition methods developed in the laboratory. Also, this project investigates the nature and extent of coupling between ferroelectric and ferromagnetic properties, especially in the few- and single layers. The primarily focus is on magnetic M2P2Q6 (M= Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Q=S, Se) and ferroelectric/ferromagnetic AMP2Q6 (A=Ag,Cu, M=In,Ga,Cr,Mn,Fe,Gd). A diverse yet integrated multimodal techniques and characterization methods are employed to unravel the complex labyrinth of microstructure across multiple length-scales. Advanced scanning and transmission electron microscopy techniques probe the local structure, phases, chemical partitioning, and related phenomena. Theoretical work conducted in close connection with the experimental efforts examines the bulk properties of materials and analyzes the meso and nano-scale phenomena in heterostrucure architectures of thio- and selenophosphates and its interaction with substrates. The scientific insights governed by unusual combination of heteroanion systems with spatial and dimensional constraints are expected to display unusual linear and non-linear ferroelectric and ferromagnetic as well as coupled properties and phenomena.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF Project Outcomes Report: Unconventional Heteroanion Ceramics

Award Title: Unconventional Heteroanion Ceramics: 2D Layered Seleno- and Thio-Phosphates

The field of materials science has been revolutionized by the discovery and development of two-dimensional (2D) materials. This National Science Foundation (NSF) funded project, titled "Unconventional Heteroanion Ceramics: 2D Layered Seleno- and Thiophosphates," has made significant strides in expanding our understanding of these fascinating materials. Over the course of this award, our research team has explored novel 2D layered structures, particularly focusing on seleno- and thio-phosphates.

Key Findings and Outcomes

1. Synthesis and Characterization of Novel 2D Materials

One of the primary achievements of this project has been the successful synthesis and characterization of new 2D layered materials. Of particular note is our work on mixed metal thiophosphates, such as Fe2-xCoxP2S6. These materials exhibit intriguing structural and magnetic properties that can be tuned by adjusting their composition. Our team developed innovative synthesis methods, including the use of P2S5 reactive flux, which allowed for rapid and controlled production of these materials.The structural evolution and anisotropy in these mixed metal systems were thoroughly investigated, providing crucial insights into how the interplay between different metal ions affects the overall properties of the material. This understanding is vital for potential applications in electronics and magnetic devices, where precise control over material properties is essential.

2. Advanced Characterization Techniques

To fully understand these complex materials, our team employed and further developed cutting-edge characterization techniques. We made significant advancements in the application of scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and valence electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) to 2D materials.A notable achievement was the development of methods to spatially map electrostatics and dynamics across 2D heterostructures. This breakthrough allows us to visualize and quantify how electric fields influence the structural and electronic properties of these materials at the nanoscale. Such detailed understanding is crucial for designing and optimizing devices based on 2D materials.We also made progress in understanding the challenges and opportunities in characterizing soft-hard interfaces using STEM. This work has broad implications for the study of hybrid materials and nanocomposites, which are increasingly important in various technological applications. 

3. Core-Shell Architectures

Our research expanded into the realm of core-shell nanostructures, with a particular focus on Si@MoS2 architectures. These novel structures combine the properties of silicon with those of transition metal dichalcogenides, opening up new possibilities in nanophotonics and optoelectronics.We conducted in-depth studies on the optical response and local dielectric function of these unconventional architectures. Our findings revealed interesting resonance couplings and optical phenomena that could be harnessed for various applications, including light manipulation at the nanoscale. We investigated structural defects in transition metal dichalcogenide core-shell architectures, providing valuable insights into how these defects influence the overall properties and performance of the materials.

4. Environmental Applications

We also explored practical applications of our research, particularly in the realm of environmental remediation. A significant outcome was the development of the Phosphate Elimination and Recovery Lightweight (PEARL) membrane. This innovative nanocomposite material shows great promise for sustainable water treatment, specifically targeting the removal and recovery of phosphates from water sources. We conducted multimodal characterization of this hierarchically porous nanocomposite, gaining a deep understanding of its structure-function relationships. This work not only advances the field of water purification but also demonstrates the broader impacts of fundamental materials research on addressing real-world environmental challenges.

5. Optical and Electronic Properties

Our investigations into the optical and electronic properties of 2D materials yielded several exciting discoveries. We studied materials like α-MoO3, uncovering their potential as polarization reflectors and color filters at visible frequencies. This work has implications for the development of novel optical devices and coatings. We also made progress in understanding and manipulating the electrostatic properties of monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides. By directly visualizing electric-field-induced structural dynamics in these materials, we gained new insights into their behavior under various conditions, which is crucial for their implementation in electronic and optoelectronic devices. 

Broader Impacts

The outcomes of this project extend far beyond the laboratory. Our work has contributed to the training of next-generation scientists and engineers, with several graduate students and postdoctoral researchers gaining valuable experience in advanced materials synthesis and characterization techniques. The fundamental understanding we've gained about structure-property relationships in 2D materials is paving the way for advancements in fields such as electronics, energy storage, and environmental technologies. Our findings on core-shell architectures and mixed metal systems open up new possibilities for designing materials with tailored properties for specific applications. Moreover, the development of new characterization techniques and methodologies will benefit the broader scientific community working on nanomaterials. These tools and approaches can be applied to a wide range of materials beyond those studied in this project, accelerating progress across multiple areas of materials science.
